body:
Please be sure that you've added the CUDA and CUDNN dlls into your PATH. 
A better solution is: copy these files into the same dir of the onnxruntime.dll that you're loading.

@snnn Thanks for the prompt reply.

I believe I do have these in the environment variables:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45402633/82512758-fe6a0680-9ade-11ea-9403-5a939426e4e5.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45402633/82512786-1a6da800-9adf-11ea-928d-17ba9687d6dd.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45402633/82512822-340eef80-9adf-11ea-8cad-9786c748708d.png)


I added cudnn files to C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v10.1 : bin, include, lib directories.

Could it be something else in my configuration?

If any other dlls are missing, would Visual Studio still give the error of not being able to find onnxruntime.dll?  Which files should I explicitly add to the output directory?

Also, whats with the dialogue I got regarding SessionOptions.cs.  Is this normal behavior or would it indicate something else?

The onnxruntime.dll depends on 

1.     advapi32.dll
2.     cublas64_10.dll
3.     cudart64_101.dll
4.     cudnn64_7.dll
5.     cufft64_10.dll
6.     curand64_10.dll
7.     kernel32.dll
8.     msvcp140.dll
9.     shlwapi.dll
10.     vcruntime140.dll
11.     vcruntime140_1.dll

Do you have all of them in your PATH ?
Closing due to inactivity. Please re-open if required.

I have the same problem after updating from 0.5.1 to 1.4.0 via nuget=>
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34069654/88788286-69962000-d195-11ea-92ad-7bf18b2d0eec.png)

@snnn where do i find all those dlls? I copied 
cublas64_100.dll
cudart64_100.dll
cudnn64_7.dll
cufft64_100.dll
curand64_100.dll

but i dont know where to look for the rest

To identify the problem:
1. Install [windbg](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/drivers/debugger/debugger-download-tools)
2.  Find the gflags.exe in the windbg install folder and start it, 

3. Select the image file tab
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/856316/74082914-91d96900-4a13-11ea-95eb-d73db8a5cf13.png)

4. Type python.exe then press the "tab" key, check "Show loader snaps" box

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/856316/74082958-b7667280-4a13-11ea-9eaf-6752695b4904.png)

5.  Put your python commands into a script file, named "test.py"
```
import torch
import onnxruntime
```

6.  Start windbg, run python.exe with arguments of "test.py"
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/856316/74083043-7d49a080-4a14-11ea-90fa-2960544a3dce.png)

7. in the command windows, type "g", then press the enter key
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/856316/74083078-d285b200-4a14-11ea-9df4-e86c421c5617.png)

7. You'll see a lot of outputs in the debugging windows.  Please search the lines that have "LdrpProcessWork - ERROR: Unable to load DLL", and put the result here.
e.g.
 "cublas64_100.dll", Parent Module: "C:\intelpython3\lib\site-packages\onnxruntime\capi\onnxruntime_pybind11_state.pyd", Status: 0xc0000135


Please post the log here if you can't find the problematic DLL by yourself.

I have the same problem as the two folks above.
**My System**
OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04): Windows 10 Pro (version 1909) x64
ONNX Runtime version: 1.4.0
Visual Studio version (if applicable): Community 2019
CUDA/cuDNN version: 10.1/7.6.5
System Python version: 3.6.8

I installed pytorch and the onnxruntime for python (though I am trying to use the onnxruntime in a winforms-based c# application) with the following commands:
- `pip install torch==1.5.0+cu101 torchvision==0.6.0+cu101 -f https://download.pytorch.org/whl/torch_stable.html`
- `pip install onnxruntime-gpu`

I can't post the output from your testing instructions, since it goes over both pastebin and github's limit, but it looks like libittnotify.dll and tbbmalloc.dll are the DLLs missing. Both seem to be related to threading on my Intel CPU, but I'm not sure why it's trying to use the CPU in the first place

Hi @celowsky 

The libittnotify.dll one is expected, it is optional. Probably it is because of something else.  Did you put CUDA and Cudnn DLLs in your PATH?

@snn Yes, I can confirm that both CUDA and Cudnn DLLs are in my path. The CheckCudaExecutionProviderDLLs() function on line 70 of SessionOptions.cs is able to load "cublas64_10.dll", "cudnn64_7.dll", and "curand64_10.dll". I've tried editing my system environment variables like @solarflarefx above and also copying the dlls straight into the same directory where the code is executing (bin\x64\Debug). 

I have two gpus in my machine: a GTX 1060 and an RTX 2070. The RTX 2070 is cuda graphics device 0 and the other card is 1.
Would you mind to sending me the windbg log outputs? My email is: chasun at microsoft.com
Can do. I just sent them over

Hi @celowsky, I couldn't find any error from it. Could you make test.py simpler? For example,  just one line of 
```python
import onnxruntime
```

Now it contains both onnxruntime and pytorch, it's hard to say who caused the failure.
Oh, I see pytorch has a private cuda copy, I guess it was not using the CUDA DLLs provided by you. And that CUDA may differs than what onnxruntime expects.
Yeah, is there a trace I could provide you with from my C# app that could help you debug?
Maybe I could try loading my system CUDA installation in python?
Execuse me, what's the goal? Do you want to use onnxruntime's C# binding and the nuget package or the python package? which one failed to load? Does the python one work?
Could you replace the Microsoft.ML.Onnxruntime.Gpu  package with Microsoft.ML.Onnxruntime and try that first? The later one has less dependencies.

Unfortunately, that still gives the exact same error. I feel like the issue may still be with how my dlls are being loaded. I notice that if I breakpoint right before the failed call and open the Modules window in Visual Studio 2019 under the **Debug > Windows** menu, `onnxruntime.dll` isn't listed, even though `Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.dll` is. 

At the top of my system path environment variable I have the following directories listed:
- C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v10.1\bin
- C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v10.1\libnvvp

If I copy the `onnxruntime.dll` file to C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA\v10.1\bin, which I think is generated by the `Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.dll` nuget package, I get a new error:

```
System.EntryPointNotFoundException: 'Unable to find an entry point named 'OrtSessionOptionsAppendExecutionProvider_CUDA' in DLL 'onnxruntime'.'
```

If it's relevant, I previously installed the CUDA 11 driver before realizing it wouldn't be compatible with the OnnxRuntime.
By default, when you install a CUDA SDK, it will add itself to PATH. But you can't have multiple CUDA SDKs in the PATH, because some of the DLLs may have the filename but totally different content.
I have since uninstalled it and manually deleted the folders left behind in C:\Program Files\NVIDIA GPU Computing Toolkit\CUDA, but I still receive the same error message

I still am unable to find out which paths are being considered during the loading of this library. I have made sure that all the files listed in @snnn 's comment are available in my path, but it seems that their location in relation to the onnxruntime.dll also matters. I've also copied those files to the `<PROJECT_ROOT>\packages\Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.Gpu.1.4.0\runtimes\win-x64\native` to no avail. This ticket should be reopened

> I still am unable to find out which paths are being considered during the loading of this library

See: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/dlls/dynamic-link-library-search-order

This issue has been automatically marked as stale due to inactivity and will be closed in 7 days if no further activity occurs. If further support is needed, please provide an update and/or more details.

Did anyone get this working?  I have the same issue.  It works fine if i use CPU but if i try an target the GPU I left with the exception System.EntryPointNotFoundException: 'Unable to find an entry point named 'OrtSessionOptionsAppendExecutionProvider_CUDA' in DLL 'onnxruntime'.'

I have checked and I have cuda 10 (only) installed, and it is added to my path.  All ML.net / dependences are 1.5.

This issue has been automatically marked as stale due to inactivity and will be closed in 7 days if no further activity occurs. If further support is needed, please provide an update and/or more details.

This problem still exists in VS 2022. Any news about 
Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.OnnxRuntimeException
  HResult=0x80131500
  Message=[ErrorCode:Fail] OrtSessionOptionsAppendExecutionProvider_Cuda: Failed to load shared library
  Source=Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime
  StackTrace:
   at Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.NativeApiStatus.VerifySuccess(IntPtr nativeStatus)
   at Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.SessionOptions.AppendExecutionProvider_CUDA(Int32 deviceId)
   at Yolov5Net.App.Program.Main(String[] args) in C:\Development\ai_image_evaluation\YoloV5\yolov5-net\src\Yolov5Net.App\Program.cs:line 22
Please see my comment above, use windbg to get more information.
